content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my earnings over the 75 rounds. Let's analyze the payoff matrix:

|     | Opponent chooses R | Opponent chooses B |
|---|---|---|
| I choose R | $45 each       | $0, opponent gets $35   |
| I choose B | opponent gets $35, I get $0 | $40 each        |

If we play the game once and both of us are rational, it's clear that we will not pick the same choice in the first round because choosing R when the opponent chooses B results in a lower payoff for me. In this case, I would choose B.

However, since the game has 75 rounds, we can expect the opponent to also adjust their strategy based on the previous choices. To maximize my earnings over the long term, I should try to exploit any patterns in my opponent's behavior, but at the same time, avoid being too predictable myself. One possible strategy could be to alternate between R and B in the first few rounds, observe the opponent's response, and then adjust my strategy accordingly.

In conclusion, while I cannot definitively say which choice I will make in the first round (it depends on how the game unfolds), I would lean towards choosing B as a starting point to potentially exploit any predictability from my opponent. I choose B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

To maximize my earnings over the long term, I should try to exploit any patterns in my opponent's behavior while avoiding being too predictable myself.
